column4: is EXT3 the best option use when installing ubuntu? as opposed to NTFS.
installing GNU/Linux (which includes Ubuntu) on NTFS is not going to work out, believe me
you could use reiserfs or xfs, but ext3 is the de-facto standard
should not be the reason for that, really, sounds like a bug, but installing on NTFS is not going to work as I said
a bug with my computer, or with the software? I heard there's an 'alternate' version of ubuntu I can try to download instead, I don't know whether that's wrong or not
maybe a software bug, but why do you want to create a NTFS partition anyways?
if you plan on creating a dual-boot environment you should install the other operating system first anyways
well my drive is NTFS to begin with and I run win xp on here, I only recently found out that linux doesn't get along with NTFS
so the other OS (windows) has already been installed
well, you cannot install (or should not) GNU/Linux on an NTFS partition, however, reading and writing should work fine
if you are trying to resize an NTFS partition make sure you defragmented that partition first

yep, so last night I downloaded a stand-alone version of gparted and booted off that, and was able to set it so that the half of my HDD with windows was NTFS, and the half I intended to install ubuntu on was EXT3. it got me a little further than before, but crashed once again
when exactly does the installer crash? you shouldn't touch the NTFS partition at all from within the installer
it crashed after I'd manually selected in the installer which 'half' (the EXT3 half) I wanted ubuntu to go on. I pressed forward to start it, and it froze after about five or ten seconds
okay, you might want to download the alternative install CD
rightio, cool. that's not the LTS one, is it? or the one for serves?
there should be an alternate install CD for the LTS version too iirc
but no, that is not the server version
is the alternate version of ubuntu essentially the same as the normal one? I can't quite seem to see a link anywhere to download it
